prompt: What is the review process for submitted papers?

prompt: What are the requirements for copyright in articles submitted to the journal?
completion: Articles submitted to the journal should not have been previously published in their current or substantially similar form, or be under consideration for publication with another journal.

prompt: Can you outline the copyright requirements for articles submitted to the journal?

prompt: What permissions do users have in terms of accessing and using the published articles?
completion: Users have permissions to read, download, copy, distribute, print, search, or link to the full texts of the articles, or use them for any other lawful purpose without asking prior permission from the publisher or the author.

prompt: Can you elaborate on the permissions granted to users regarding access and utilization of the published articles?

prompt: What rights do users possess in relation to accessing and utilizing the articles published in the journal?

prompt: What permissions do authors need to obtain prior to article submission?
completion: Authors need to obtain permission to use any content that has not been created by them prior to article submission.

prompt: What permissions are required for authors before submitting an article?
completion: Authors are required to seek permission before using content not created by them when submitting an article.

prompt: What kind of permissions should authors acquire before submitting their article?
completion: Prior to article submission, authors must acquire permission to utilize content that is not their own.

prompt: What are the rights that Emerald requires in relation to the material used in the article?
completion: Emerald requires non-exclusive rights to reproduce the material in the article or book chapter, print and electronic rights, worldwide English language rights, and the ability to use the material for the life of the work without time restrictions.

prompt: What rights does Emerald expect for the material used in the article?
completion: Emerald necessitates the right to reproduce the material in the article or book chapter, both in print and electronic formats, along with worldwide English language rights, and unrestricted use of the material for the duration of the work.

prompt: What rights are necessary for Emerald regarding the material used in the article?
completion: In relation to the material used in the article, Emerald expects non-exclusive rights for reproduction, both in print and electronic form, as well as worldwide English language rights, without any time limitations.

prompt: What is expected of authors when reproducing tables, figures, or excerpts from another source?
completion: When reproducing tables, figures, or excerpts from another source, authors are expected to obtain the necessary written permission in advance from any third-party owners of copyright for the use of their text, illustrations, graphics, or other material in print and electronic formats. They must also clear permission for any minor adaptations of work not created by them. Additionally, authors must acknowledge the source in figure captions and refer to it in the reference list.

prompt: What are the author's responsibilities when reproducing tables, figures, or excerpts from another source?
completion: Authors reproducing tables, figures, or excerpts from other sources should acquire written permission beforehand from the respective copyright owners for using their material in print and electronic formats. They should also obtain clearance for any minor adaptations of non-original work. Moreover, authors must appropriately acknowledge the source in figure captions and include it in the reference list.

prompt: What should authors do when using tables, figures, or excerpts from another source?
completion: When authors include tables, figures, or excerpts from external sources, they should secure written permission in advance from the relevant copyright holders to use their content in both print and electronic formats. Additionally, authors must obtain clearance for any minor modifications made to material not created by them. Furthermore, it is important for authors to acknowledge the source in figure captions and provide a reference in the list.

prompt: How should authors handle minor adaptations of work not created by them?
completion: Authors should inform the copyright holder of the original work when they adapt significantly any material not created by them.

prompt: What is the recommended approach for authors when making minor adaptations of work not created by them?

prompt: How are authors supposed to deal with minor changes to work not created by them?
completion: When authors make significant adaptations to material not of their own creation, they are responsible for informing the copyright holder of the original work.

prompt: Should authors assume that freely available web content is free to use?

prompt: Is it safe for authors to assume that freely available web content can be used without permission?

prompt: Can authors consider freely available web content as free for use without any restrictions?

prompt: What is the role of the Committee on Publication Ethics (COPE)?
completion: The role of the Committee on Publication Ethics (COPE) is to provide advice on all aspects of publication ethics and support the development and practical application of consistent ethical standards throughout the scholarly publishing community.

prompt: What responsibilities does the Committee on Publication Ethics (COPE) have?
completion: The Committee on Publication Ethics (COPE) plays a role in offering guidance on publication ethics and fostering the implementation of ethical standards in the scholarly publishing community.

prompt: What is the purpose of the Committee on Publication Ethics (COPE)?
completion: COPE's role involves providing guidance on publication ethics and promoting the adoption of consistent ethical standards within the scholarly publishing community.

prompt: What is the purpose of signing a Creative Commons Attribution Licence 4.0 (CC BY 4.0) upon acceptance of an article?
completion: The purpose of signing a Creative Commons Attribution Licence 4.0 (CC BY 4.0) upon acceptance of an article is to retain copyright in the article while granting Emerald a license to publish the article and identify itself as the original publisher. The license allows the article to be freely shared, copied, adapted and used for any purpose, even commercially, as long as full attribution to the original work is included in any derivatives.

prompt: What does signing a Creative Commons Attribution Licence 4.0 (CC BY 4.0) serve after an article is accepted?
completion: By signing a Creative Commons Attribution Licence 4.0 (CC BY 4.0) upon article acceptance, authors maintain copyright of the article while granting Emerald the license to publish it and be recognized as the original publisher. The license permits unrestricted sharing, copying, adaptation, and commercial use of the article, provided that proper attribution is given in any derivative works.

prompt: What is the significance of agreeing to a Creative Commons Attribution Licence 4.0 (CC BY 4.0) when an article is accepted?
completion: The purpose of signing a Creative Commons Attribution Licence 4.0 (CC BY 4.0) after an article is accepted is to retain the copyright of the article while granting Emerald the right to publish it and be acknowledged as the original publisher. This license allows for the article to be freely shared, copied, adapted, and used commercially, with the condition that proper attribution to the original work is included in any derivatives.

completion: Authors fulfill the requirements of the CC BY 4.0 license through ScholarOne. After receiving an email with links to the license form, they are required to review the form for accuracy and submit it electronically.

prompt: How should publications be cited within the text?

prompt: What is the proper way to cite publications in the text?

prompt: In what manner should publications be referenced within the text?

prompt: can you share the message from the RIC Director of PSU?
completion: "In the last few years, Prince Sultan University has increasingly given research more attention and weight. This finally contributed to the establishment of the Research and Initiatives Center (RIC in short), in September 2017. Since then, the University has taken several brave decisions to promote research and has resulted in several new research programs and initiatives. First, the University adopted a decentralized strategy for research governance, giving colleges their financial independence and decision making about conference attendance, project proposal evaluation, research labs, to name a few. This change from the fully centralized research strategy to a decentralized one has radically improved the research productivity and increased the motivation of researchers. Besides, several research programs were established, allowing faculty members to invite top scholars as distinguished visiting professors, and also invite Ph.D. students from abroad for research internships of one to six months. These are just a sample of the initiatives that Prince Sultan University has made, and that resulted in a highly positive impact on the research environment. At PSU, we are very proud and enthusiastic about the achievements made in research, and we are working forward to reach the highest level of excellence in research in the near future. I also take this opportunity to acknowledge and thank the efforts of the previous RIC Director Dr. Khaled Almustafa and his team for paving the way to a productive research environment and we do hope to continue this success."

prompt: Could you provide the message from the RIC Director of PSU?
completion: "Over the past few years, Prince Sultan University has placed increasing emphasis on research. This led to the establishment of the Research and Initiatives Center (RIC) in September 2017. Since then, the University has made bold decisions to promote research, resulting in the implementation of new research programs and initiatives. One significant change was the adoption of a decentralized research governance strategy, granting colleges financial independence and decision-making authority in areas such as conference attendance, project proposal evaluation, and research labs. This shift from a fully centralized to a decentralized approach has greatly enhanced research productivity and researcher motivation. Additionally, several research programs were introduced, allowing faculty members to invite renowned scholars as distinguished visiting professors and hosting Ph.D. students from abroad for research internships ranging from one to six months. These are just a few examples of the initiatives that have had a highly positive impact on the research environment at Prince Sultan University. We take immense pride and enthusiasm in our research achievements and remain committed to attaining the highest level of research excellence in the future. I would also like to express gratitude to the previous RIC Director, Dr. Khaled Almustafa, and his team for laying the foundation for a productive research environment, and we aspire to build upon their success."

prompt: Can you share the message conveyed by the RIC Director of PSU?
completion: "In recent years, Prince Sultan University has progressively given greater attention and significance to research. This culminated in the establishment of the Research and Initiatives Center (RIC) in September 2017. Subsequently, the University has implemented several bold measures to foster research, leading to the inception of various new research programs and initiatives. Notably, the University adopted a decentralized research governance strategy, empowering individual colleges with financial autonomy and decision-making authority in areas such as conference participation, project proposal evaluation, and research laboratory operations. This transition from a fully centralized research strategy to a decentralized one has yielded remarkable improvements in research productivity and heightened the motivation of researchers. Moreover, the University has established numerous research programs that facilitate the invitation of esteemed scholars as distinguished visiting professors and enable the engagement of Ph.D. students from abroad in research internships lasting from one to six months. These initiatives exemplify the profound positive impact they have had on the research ecosystem at Prince Sultan University. We take immense pride in and are deeply enthusiastic about the accomplishments we have made in research, as we strive to attain the utmost level of research excellence in the near future. I would also like to express my appreciation and gratitude to the former RIC Director, Dr. Khaled Almustafa, and his team for their instrumental role in laying the groundwork for a thriving research environment. We are determined to build upon their success and sustain this momentum of growth."

prompt: What is the message conveyed by the RIC Director of PSU?
completion: "In recent years, Prince Sultan University has placed greater emphasis on research and established the Research and Initiatives Center (RIC) in September 2017. The university has implemented various initiatives to promote research, including a decentralized research governance strategy that grants colleges financial independence and decision-making authority. This change has significantly improved research productivity and motivated researchers. Additionally, the university has introduced research programs that allow faculty members to invite distinguished visiting professors and host Ph.D. students from abroad for research internships. These efforts have positively impacted the research environment at Prince Sultan University, and we are proud of our research achievements. I would like to acknowledge the contributions of the former RIC Director, Dr. Khaled Almustafa, and his team for establishing a productive research environment. We remain committed to excellence in research and aim to continue our success in the future."

prompt: How does the STU ensure the compliance of research proposals with scientific integrity rules?

prompt: What is the general grade assigned to the cumulative GPA at the time of a student's graduation?

prompt: What is the GPA range for a student to receive an "Excellent" grade at graduation?
completion: To receive an "Excellent" grade at graduation, a student's cumulative GPA must be no less than 4.50 out of 5.00 or 3.50 out of 4.00.

prompt: At graduation, what is the GPA range required for a student to receive an "Excellent" grade?
completion: In order to receive an "Excellent" grade upon graduation, a student must have a cumulative GPA of at least 4.50 out of 5.00 or 3.50 out of 4.00.

prompt: What is the minimum and maximum GPA needed to achieve an "Excellent" grade at graduation?
completion: Graduating students are eligible to receive an "Excellent" grade if their cumulative GPA is equal to or greater than 4.50 out of 5.00 or 3.50 out of 4.00.

prompt: What are the GPA ranges for a student to receive a "Very Good," "Good," or "Pass" grade at graduation?
completion: The GPA ranges for a student to receive a "Very Good," "Good," or "Pass" grade at graduation are as follows: for Very Good, the cumulative GPA must be 3.75 or higher but less than 4.50 (out of 5.00), or 2.75 or higher but less than 3.50 (out of 4.00); for Good, the cumulative GPA must be 2.75 or higher but less than 3.75 (out of 5.00), or 1.75 or higher but less than 2.75 (out of 4.00); for Pass, the cumulative GPA must be 2.00 or higher but less than 2.75 (out of 5.00), or 1.00 or higher but less than 1.75 (out of 4.00).

prompt: Can you provide me with the GPA ranges needed to receive a "Very Good," "Good," or "Pass" grade at graduation?
completion: To earn a "Very Good," "Good," or "Pass" grade upon graduation, a student's cumulative GPA must fall within specific ranges, ranging from 3.75 to 2.00 out of 5.00 or 2.75 to 1.00 out of 4.00, depending on the grade.

prompt: What is the minimum and maximum GPA required to obtain a "Very Good," "Good," or "Pass" grade at graduation?
completion: Graduating students can receive different grades - Very Good, Good, or Pass - based on their cumulative GPA, which must fall within specific ranges for each grade.

prompt: What is the GPA range for a student to earn first honors at graduation?
completion: A student must earn a cumulative GPA between 4.75 and 5.00 (out of 5.00) or between 3.75 and 4.00 (out of 4.00) to receive first honors at graduation.

prompt: What is the minimum and maximum GPA needed for a student to achieve first honors at graduation?

prompt: Can you tell me the GPA range required for a student to earn first honors at graduation?
completion: Graduating students will receive first honors if their cumulative GPA is between 4.75 and 5.00 out of 5.00 or between 3.75 and 4.00 out of 4.00.

prompt: What is the GPA range for a student to earn second honors at graduation?
completion: A student must earn a cumulative GPA of 4.50 or higher but less than 4.75 (out of 5.00), or 3.50 or higher but less than 3.75 (out of 4.00) to receive second honors at graduation.

prompt: At graduation, what is the GPA range required for a student to receive second honors?
completion: Second honors at graduation require a cumulative GPA of 4.50-4.75 (out of 5.00) or 3.50-3.75 (out of 4.00).

prompt: What is the minimum and maximum GPA needed to achieve second honors at graduation?
completion: To be eligible for second honors at graduation, a student's cumulative GPA should be within 4.50-4.75 (out of 5.00) or 3.50-3.75 (out of 4.00) range.

prompt: What criteria must a student meet to be eligible for first or second honors at graduation?
completion: To be eligible for first or second honors at graduation, a student must not have failed any course completed at the University or any other university, completed all graduation requirements within a specified period, the maximum of which is the average of the maximum and minimum limits for completing his/her degree program, and have completed 60 percent or more of the graduation requirements at the university from which he/she is graduating.

prompt: What are the requirements that a student needs to meet to be eligible for either first or second honors at graduation?
completion: Students must fulfill certain criteria such as passing all courses, meeting graduation requirements within a set time period, and completing at least 60% of the requirements at the university to be eligible for first or second honors at graduation.

prompt: Can you list the criteria that a student must fulfill to be eligible for first or second honors at graduation?
completion: Meeting the criteria for eligibility, such as passing all courses, completing graduation requirements within the time limit, and satisfying the university requirement of completing 60% or more of graduation requirements, is necessary for students to receive first or second honors at graduation.

completion: A student can earn the rank of "Excellent" for an academic year if he/she receives one of the distinction ranks in both the first and second semesters of the same year.

completion: To achieve the rank of "Excellent" for an academic year, a student must attain one of the distinction ranks in both the first and second semesters of the same year.

prompt: How is a student's cumulative GPA recalculated?

prompt: What are the rules governing the recalculation of the cumulative GPA?
completion: The rules governing the recalculation of the cumulative GPA include: excluding a grade earned previously in any completed course if the student has repeated the course successfully and earned a grade of D or higher, excluding certain grades (F, DN, WF, D and D+) from the total number of credits used to calculate the student's cumulative GPA, excluding a maximum of 24 credits when calculating the cumulative GPA, indicating the courses that have been excluded from the calculation of the GPA by a special mark in the academic record, and clearly indicating the cumulative GPA after excluding the grades of the repeated courses.

prompt: What policies govern the recalculation of a student's GPA at Prince Sultan University?
completion: The regulations for recalculating the cumulative GPA involve: removing the previously earned grade for any course if the student repeats and earns a grade of D or higher, excluding specific grades (F, DN, WF, D, and D+) from the calculation of the cumulative GPA, disregarding up to 24 credits when determining the cumulative GPA, marking the courses that have been excluded from the GPA calculation in the student's academic record, and displaying the cumulative GPA after eliminating the repeated course grades.

prompt: What regulations dictate how a student's cumulative GPA is recalculated?
completion: The rules that apply to recalculating the cumulative GPA require that grades earned previously in any completed course be excluded if the student repeats the course successfully and earns a grade of D or higher, that certain grades (F, DN, WF, D, and D+) are not counted towards the cumulative GPA, that a maximum of 24 credits can be excluded when calculating the cumulative GPA, that a special mark is used in the academic record to indicate the courses that have been excluded from the GPA calculation, and that the cumulative GPA is displayed after eliminating the grades of the repeated courses.

prompt: What are the conditions that must be met for a student to be accepted for transfer to PSU?
completion: The conditions that must be met for a student to be accepted for transfer to PSU are: no more than 45 credit hours (beyond the PYP) can be transferred for the student, the course to be transferred should have been taught using the same language in which the equivalent course is being taught at PSU, for a course to be considered for transfer, the student must have obtained a minimum of (C) grade in that course, the course must be equivalent in content and in the number of credit hours to a course that is being taught at PSU, the student should have been enrolled at a college or university that is recognized by the Ministry of Education (MOE), the transferred courses must have been studied within the last five semesters before the transfer, the student must not have been dismissed from that university for disciplinary reasons, and the student must satisfy any other transfer provisions as determined by the University Council.

prompt: What is the purpose of the Student Council at Prince Sultan University?
completion: The purpose of the Student Council at Prince Sultan University is to give students opportunities to develop communication, problem-solving, and leadership skills by organizing and carrying out university activities and service projects.

prompt: What is the aim of the Student Council at Prince Sultan University?
completion: The main objective of the Student Council at Prince Sultan University is to enable students to enhance their communication, problem-solving, and leadership skills through organizing and executing university events and community projects.

prompt: What does the Student Council at Prince Sultan University intend to achieve?
completion: By organizing and conducting university activities and service projects, the Student Council at Prince Sultan University aims to provide students with opportunities to develop communication, problem-solving, and leadership skills.

prompt: Who supervises the Student Council?
completion: The Student Council is supervised by the Dean of Student Affairs.

prompt: Who oversees the activities of the Student Council?
completion: The Dean of Student Affairs is responsible for overseeing the activities of the Student Council.

prompt: Who is in charge of managing the Student Council?
completion: The Student Council is under the supervision of the Dean of Student Affairs.

prompt: What skills can students develop by participating in the Student Council?
completion: Students can develop communication, problem-solving, and leadership skills by participating in the Student Council.

prompt: What abilities can students acquire through their involvement in the Student Council?
completion: Participation in the Student Council can help students to enhance their communication, problem-solving, and leadership skills.

prompt: In what ways can participating in the Student Council help students enhance their skills?
completion: By joining the Student Council, students can develop skills such as communication, problem-solving, and leadership.

prompt: How are ideas presented and confirmed by the Student Council?
completion: Ideas are presented, voted on, and confirmed by the majority vote following parliamentary procedures and protocol.

prompt: What is the process for presenting and approving ideas in the Student Council?
completion: Following parliamentary procedures and protocols, ideas are presented, voted on, and approved by the majority vote.

prompt: How are suggestions introduced and verified by the Student Council?
completion: The Student Council follows parliamentary procedures and protocols when presenting, voting on, and confirming ideas by the majority vote.

prompt: How can students nominate themselves for election to the Student Council?
completion: Students can nominate themselves for election to the Student Council by showing their interest and submitting their nomination during the nomination period.

prompt: What is the procedure for self-nomination to the Student Council?
completion: During the nomination period, students can show their interest and nominate themselves for election to the Student Council.

prompt: How can students put themselves forward as candidates for the Student Council?
completion: To be elected to the Student Council, students need to nominate themselves during the nomination period by expressing their interest.

prompt: How are nominees selected for the Student Council?
completion: Nominees for the Student Council are selected based on the review of their applications by the Deanship of Student Affairs, as long as no violations exist. Afterward, an election process starts online, and the highest 9 nominees combined with three students from the previous council are selected.

prompt: What is the process for choosing candidates for the Student Council?
completion: The Deanship of Student Affairs reviews the applications of the nominees for the Student Council, and if no violations are found, an online election process starts, and the nine highest nominees are selected, along with three students from the previous council.

prompt: What criteria are used to pick nominees for the Student Council?
completion: The Deanship of Student Affairs reviews the applications of the nominees for the Student Council to ensure no violations exist before starting an online election process. The nine highest nominees are selected, along with three students from the previous council.

prompt: What is the role of the Student Council Advisory Board?
completion: The role of the Student Council Advisory Board is to review, determine the feasibility, and confer on the implementation of the proposals set forth by the Student Council.

prompt: What are the responsibilities of the Student Council Advisory Board?
completion: The Student Council Advisory Board reviews, assesses the feasibility, and approves the implementation of proposals made by the Student Council.

prompt: How does the Student Council Advisory Board contribute to the Student Council's activities?
completion: The Student Council Advisory Board is responsible for evaluating, determining the feasibility of, and providing feedback on the implementation of proposals submitted by the Student Council.

prompt: Who chairs the mentor program at Prince Sultan University?
completion: The mentor program at Prince Sultan University is chaired by the Student Council.

prompt: Who is responsible for leading the mentor program at Prince Sultan University?
completion: The Student Council is responsible for chairing the mentor program at Prince Sultan University.

prompt: Who is the head of the mentor program at Prince Sultan University?
completion: The chair of the mentor program at Prince Sultan University is held by the Student Council.

prompt: What is the purpose of the mentor program?
completion: The purpose of the mentor program is to ensure that students always have a place to refer back to with regards to any complications they might have by providing the best advice to their mentees.

prompt: What is the aim of the mentor program?
completion: The mentor program aims to provide students with a reliable place to seek advice and support when encountering difficulties by offering the best guidance to their mentees.

prompt: Why does Prince Sultan University have a mentor program?
completion: By providing the best advice to their mentees, the mentor program ensures that students always have a trustworthy source to turn to when facing any complications.

prompt: What types of student clubs are offered by the Deanship of Student Affairs at Prince Sultan University?
completion: The Deanship of Student Affairs offers two types of student clubs: academic and non-academic.

prompt: What are the categories of student clubs provided by the Deanship of Student Affairs at Prince Sultan University?
completion: At Prince Sultan University, students have the option of joining either academic or non-academic clubs offered by the Deanship of Student Affairs.

prompt: What kinds of clubs can students find at Prince Sultan University under the Deanship of Student Affairs?
completion: Students enrolled in Prince Sultan University can opt to become a member of academic or non-academic organizations provided by the Office of Student Affairs.

prompt: What are some examples of activities offered by the student clubs at Prince Sultan University?
completion: Some examples of activities organized by student clubs at Prince Sultan University include a UX Design Workshop hosted by the Digital Media Club, a KACST internship program offered by the EdTech Club, and the Communication and Leadership Skills program provided by the PSU Toastmasters Club.

prompt: What are some illustrations of events and programs available through the student clubs at Prince Sultan University?
completion: The student clubs at Prince Sultan University offer a wide range of activities, including a UX Design Workshop by the Digital Media Club, a KACST internship program by the EdTech Club, and the Communication and Leadership Skills initiative provided by the PSU Toastmasters Club.

prompt: What activities and initiatives are offered by the student clubs at Prince Sultan University?
completion: Prince Sultan University's student organizations present a diverse array of programs, such as the Digital Media Club's UX Design Workshop, the EdTech Club's KACST internship program, and the PSU Toastmasters Club's Communication and Leadership Skills initiative.

prompt: How many books can I borrow?
completion: Students and administrative staff can borrow five (5) general books for one month. Faculty is allowed to borrow twenty (20) books for the whole semester.

prompt: What is the maximum number of books that I'm allowed to borrow?
completion: Borrowing privileges for general books are limited to five (5) books for students and administrative staff for one month, and twenty (20) books for faculty members for the entire semester.

prompt: Is there a limit to the number of books I can borrow from the library?
completion: A maximum of five (5) general books can be borrowed by students and administrative staff for one month, and twenty (20) books can be borrowed by faculty for the whole semester.

prompt: Can I borrow reference sources, journals, newspapers and magazines?
completion: Reference sources, journals, newspapers and magazines are categorized as IN-LIBRARY USE material therefore can be borrowed for limited time only with special permission of Circulation Librarian at Central Library.

prompt: Is it possible for me to check out reference materials, journals, newspapers, and magazines?
completion: IN-LIBRARY USE materials such as reference sources, journals, newspapers, and magazines are only available for borrowing with special permission from the Circulation Librarian at the Central Library.

prompt: Are reference sources, journals, newspapers, and magazines available for borrowing?
completion: The borrowing period for reference sources, journals, newspapers, and magazines is limited to a specific time, and only with the approval of the Circulation Librarian at the Central Library.

prompt: Are group activities and discussions allowed inside the Library?
completion: Yes, but only in assigned areas in library. The conducive learning environment of the library should be maintained by not disturbing other library users.

prompt: Is it permissible to engage in group activities and discussions within the Library?
completion: While group activities and discussions are permitted in the library, they are only allowed in designated areas to maintain a conducive learning environment for other library users.

prompt: Are group activities and discussions allowed in the Library's premises?
completion: Group activities and discussions are allowed within the library, but must be confined to designated areas to avoid disturbing other library users.

prompt: How can I recommend a book for purchase?
completion: Faculty and students are encouraged to recommend books and other material for purchase: For material in English language, requests are sent to iabid@psu.edu.sa For material in Arabic language, requests are sent to aaldakhil@psu.edu.sa

prompt: What is the process for suggesting a book to be purchased by the library?
completion: The library encourages both faculty and students to suggest books and other materials for purchase. Requests for materials in English should be sent to iabid@psu.edu.sa, and for Arabic materials to aaldakhil@psu.edu.sa.

prompt: How can I make a recommendation for the library to purchase a particular book?
completion: Both students and faculty members are encouraged to suggest materials for purchase, with requests for English materials sent to iabid@psu.edu.sa and for Arabic materials to aaldakhil@psu.edu.sa.

prompt: Are there printers that can produce color copies in the Library?

prompt: What do I do if online databases are not accessible?

prompt: What steps should I take if I can't access online databases?

prompt: What should I do if I encounter difficulties accessing online databases?

completion: Please report the problem to the nearby staff at the Library.

prompt: If printers, computers, scanners, or other IT equipment are not functioning, what should I do?

prompt: How do I find materials in Library?
completion: The Library's Classification System has ten (10) main classes for sorting materials by subject, and the Central Library at PSU employs an integrated library management system and an online public access catalog (OPAC) for managing collections, circulation, and searching. Access the catalog at http://clopac.psu.edu.sa and search for materials using the OPAC, write down the call number, and use the 3M self-check system to check out materials directly from the shelves. If you need help, any library staff member can assist you.

prompt: What is the process for locating materials in the Library?
completion: PSU Central Library employs an integrated library management system that includes an online public access catalog (OPAC) and a classification system with ten (10) main classes for sorting materials according to subject. To check out materials, search the catalog at http://clopac.psu.edu.sa, write down the call number, and use the 3M self-check system. If you require assistance, ask any available library staff member.

prompt: How can I search for and locate materials in the Library's collection?
completion: The PSU Central Library uses an integrated library management system with an online public access catalog (OPAC) and a ten (10) main class classification system for categorizing materials by subject. To borrow materials, access the catalog at http://clopac.psu.edu.sa, locate the call number, and use the 3M self-check system. If you need assistance, don't hesitate to ask any of the library's available staff members.

prompt: I am off campus. How can I access PSU Digital Library?

prompt: What are the methods available for me to access PSU Digital Library when I'm not on campus?

prompt: Is it possible to access PSU Digital Library from off-campus, and if so, how?
completion: Subscribed electronic resources from the Central Library can be accessed off-campus by PSU students and faculty using their PSU email ID and password at https://ezproxy.psu.edu.sa.

prompt: Does PSU Libraries offer scanning services? If affirmative, what are the guidelines for using them?

prompt: What equipment can users borrow from the library, and what are the requirements for borrowing?

prompt: What are the devices that can be borrowed by users from the library, and what are the conditions for borrowing?

prompt: What equipment is available for borrowing at the library, and what are the borrowing requirements?

prompt: What is the Library Online Survey, and who can participate in it?

prompt: Tell me about Law 001: Legal TERMINOLOGIES IN ENGLISH I
completion: This course is a core component of the Preparatory Year Program (PYP) who are intending to read for the Bachelor of Laws (LL.B.) degree offered by PSU. The course will provide the students with a broad overview of definitions, institutions, sources, systems, substantive and procedural laws within Saudi Arabian, British and American law. Additionally, the students will also be taught the fundamentals of legal research and the basic skills of a lawyer dealing with a client. This course paves the way for a more in-depth study of the law in Law 002.

The course will provide the students with a broad overview of definitions, institutions, sources, systems, substantive and procedural laws within Saudi Arabian, British and American law. Additionally, the students will also be taught the fundamentals of legal research and the basic skills of a lawyer dealing with a client. This course paves the way for a more in-depth study of the law in Law 002.

prompt: Tell me about Law 002: LEGAL TERMINOLOGY II
completion: This course is a core component of the Preparatory Year Program (PYP) Students who are intending to read for the Bachelor of Laws (LL.B.) degree offered by PSU. The course is to introduce the students to some specific areas of law such as contract law, the law of torts, property law, and intellectual property, all within the context of the British legal system, and to provide students with an opportunity to see how rules and principles can be applied to particular factual situations.

prompt: Tell me about Law 101: PRINCIPLES OF LAW (A)
completion: This course is a core component of the first year of the Bachelor of Laws program offered by PSU. The course explores the theory of law and rights. It is designed to provide the students with the following: the concept of law and the characteristics of legal rules, different types of law, resources of legal rules, how law is interpreted and the agencies that apply the law. In addition, it considers the definition, typologies, and sources of rights, who enjoys certain rights and how rights can be implemented and forfeited.

completion: The general theory of obligations is considered one of the important theories in law. Therefore, this course is a prerequisite for LAW 223. It provides an inclusive overview of theory of obligation, willful sources (contracts and unilateral act) and non-willful sources (tort and unjust enrichment).

prompt: Tell me about Law 112: LAW OF TORT (E)
completion: This is an obligatory course. This course is designed to provide students with a general introduction and critical understanding of Tort Law, providing general concepts and theories of the law of torts from a common law and comparative civil law perspective. It differentiates between a civil and a criminal wrong. It encompasses a representative range of several types of civil wrongs from a common law perspective: negligence, defamation, nuisance, intentional torts, nervous shock, misrepresentation, strict liability, occupiers liability, and vicarious liability and compares them to the analysis under comparative civil law.

prompt: Tell me about Law 150: ADMINISTRATIVE LAW 1 (A)
completion: This course is one of the important courses of administrative law. It covers the genesis of administrative law, state administrative organization, public facilities, administrative discipline, civil service, administrative decisions, and public funds. These topics are important for law students, as they form the principles of organizing administrative authority, administrative work in the state. Thus, this course is necessary to ensure great understanding of legal provisions and achieving the states public interest at an individual and authority level.

prompt: Tell me about HIST 151: HISTORY OF LAW
completion: Students who plan to work in almost any area of law, as well as those interested in the academic study of legal history have much to gain from this History of Law course elective. The Program of Study in Law and History offers students a chance to examine law and its relationship to the larger world of philosophy, religion, politics, and government - in the context of studying law in a period of time, different from our own. It is designed to reflect the present evolution of interdisciplinary university education in our rapidly changing world. Law and History offers students a chance to contrast our present circumstances with the past, a chance to understand the long path of development that led to the legal problems we grapple with in the present, and the chance to see the deep roots of the social forces that are changing the shape of our own world.

prompt: Tell me about Law 152: CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (E)
completion: The course Constitutional Law is a first-year course that highlights the importance of constitutionalism all around the world. The course focuses mainly on the Constitutions of three countries: the United States of America, the United Kingdom and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The approach of presenting these three countries allows students to compare the different legal systems and provides them with the basic and general knowledge of constitutional law.

prompt: Tell me about HIST 153: COMPARATIVE POLITICAL SYSTEMS
completion: This course is an elective course on Comparative Political systems. This course offers a broad introduction to comparative politics, the subfield of political science concerned mainly with political ideas, institutions, and behavior within states. Politics, the distribution, exercise, and consequences of power - exists at multiple levels of our society and in our daily lives. We experience politics in action, for example, during international negotiations, government policy choices, in the workplace, and in our own families. This course focuses on the formal, public sphere of politics and power relations through a systematic study and comparison of types of government and political systems.

prompt: Tell me about Law 170: FAMILY LAW (A)
completion: This course covers family law and the legal provisions related to it. For example, marriage, its pillars, conditions, impacts, and divorce and its impacts. It also covers other types of couples separation, such as Khul divorce, dissolution of marriage contract or due to a flaw, custody, and infant feeding. In this course, the students will learn the Legal conduct of personal status, as it shows the mainstays of the family and stresses on the duties and rights of each member. In addition, it will allow the students to acquire knowledge, in terms of settling families disputes and personal statuss related cases.

prompt: Tell me about Law 172: FUNDAMENTALS OF JURISPRUDENCE (A)
completion: The course offers an introduction for law students about doctrinal rules. It explains its four pillars which are; the evidence (and its types), the signified (the consideration of judgment, the judge, the convict), the connotations (abrogation, its types, its provisions), and the inferred (ijtihad, qualifications of the mujtahid, types of ijtihad, the provisions of ijtihad- imitation - fatwa). By the end of this course, students will be able to link between the legal text and the legal provision based on it, clarify the reasons for the practical provisions and the goal behind them, and write reports in the light of the legal provisions and legal evidence topics.

prompt: Tell me about Law 213: THEORIES OF OBLIGATION PROVISIONS (A)
completion: This course is considered part 2 of civil law courses of Bachelor of Laws program offered by Prince Sultan University. In this course, the students will be able to complete what they took in LAW111&LAW112. This course covers the effects of obligation, natural obligation, civil obligation, modified descriptions of obligation effects, condition and deadlines, multiple obligation, multiple obligation parties, and means of preserving the rights of creditors in implementation. Furthermore, the course covers transfer of obligation, assignment of right, assignment of debt, methods of fulfillment or equivalent to fulfillment of compliance obligation, fulfillment in return, renewal, deputation in fulfillment, compensation, collective liabilities, and compliance obligation without fulfillment.

prompt: Tell me about Law 223: LAW OF CONTRACTS I (A)
completion: This course is one of the civil law courses series. It covers contract theory. Therefore, the students in this course are introduced to the most important provisions and issues related to the most common civil contracts, namely sales and lease contracts, by focusing on how they are created, implemented, and expired. In addition, the most important provisions related to the general terms and conditions of these contracts. It covers as well how to resolve civil conflict related to sale and rent by reviewing precedents from Saudi courts and international arbitration committees.

prompt: Tell me about Law 230: ARABIC LEGAL WRITING (A)
completion: This course introduces the students to practices, procedures and protocols of legal writing in Arabic. The focus is on the Arabic language and drafting of different legal documents, including various pleadings and defense documents, drafting contracts, conducting legal research, writing legal memos, providing legal consultations, and presenting their work in writing and in oral argument. This course is designed to prepare the students for the job market in accordance with the targeted legal areas.

prompt: Tell me about Law 231: ENGLISH LEGAL WRITING (E)
completion: The course is an obligatory course. It aims to give practical training to law students about writing, drafting legal documents. These documents are considered essential part of any law degree. Students receive first-hand experience of what a law firm require in legal writing, once they join the job market. The course has various areas of legal written practice of making documents for clients and court proceedings like pleading papers or contracts. Students will have opportunities to learn and apply their legal English skills by becoming familiar with resources available to students, observing real-world legal situations

prompt: Tell me about Law 320: LABOR LAW AND SOCIAL SECURITY (A)
completion: This course is concerned with the organization of labor relations according to the employment contract in the private sector, employment contracts for employees Under Budget wagetory item or in the public sector. It covers the most important provisions related to the establishment, implementation and termination of the employment contracts of a Saudi and foreign employee and how to resolve disputes related to them. The reason behind linking the Labor Law to the Insurance Law is that the two are an integral part of the other. In addition, the Insurance Law is the law under which the employee remains after the end of his contractual relationship that is protected by the Labor Law in order to face social risks and obtain the pension.

prompt: Tell me about Law 243: COMMERCIAL LAW I (A)
completion: This course is part 1 of the Commercial Law System. It covers three sections: the first one introduces Commercial Law, by indicating the scope of Commercial Law application, the criteria of differentiating commercial from civil transactions, and the effects of the distinction between them. The second section explains the conditions for acquiring the status of a trader, its obligations, and the commercial place and its required licenses. As for the third section, it covers the definitions of commercial papers, their types (the bill of exchange, the promissory note and the check), their creation, their circulation, and the guarantees of their fulfillment.

prompt: Tell me about Law 255: PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW (E)
completion: This course is an obligatory course. This course focuses on the relations between states, international organizations, and other legal actors within the public international framework. It explores competing notions of sovereignty and the dilemma of conflict resolution between parties under international law. Special attention will be paid to the recognition of states and the consequent obligations of states, the law of treaties, and topical issues in international law, for example illegal settling of territories, the law of the sea, the requirements and obstacles of state formation and humanitarian law.

prompt: Tell me about Law 262: CRIMINAL LAW I (A)
completion: The course introduces Theory of Crime and Theory of Sanction in Sharia and law. It is presented in three parts: Part I - defines crime and lists its characteristics, divisions, and types (legal, material, moral). Part II- deals with the study of the criminal in terms of defining his role as a contributor to the crime, as being directly involved in the crime (original contribution) or a co-creator (associative contribution), according to the acts he committed. In addition, this part is concerned with the statement of the criminal responsibility for what is attributed to him and the availability of the eligibility conditions at the time of committing the crime (perception, freedom of choice). Furthermore, it covers the obstacles of criminal responsibility that may result, under certain conditions, in the absence of criminal responsibility or the removal of the criminal character of the act. Part III- introduces the Theory of Sanction, its divisions, types, and individualization. Moreover, it indicates the reasons for mitigating and aggravating the sanction, the methods of execution, its suspension, its limitations, its alternatives, and the effects of its implementation.

completion: The course introduces Theory of Crime and Theory of Sanction in Sharia and law. It is presented in three parts: Part I - defines crime and lists its characteristics, divisions, and types (legal, material, moral). Part II- deals with the study of the criminal in terms of defining his role as a contributor to the crime, as being directly involved in the crime (original contribution) or a co-creator (associative contribution), according to the acts he committed. In addition, this part is concerned with the statement of the criminal responsibility for what is attributed to him and the availability of the eligibility conditions at the time of committing the crime (perception, freedom of choice). Furthermore, it covers the obstacles of criminal responsibility that may result, under certain conditions, in the absence of criminal responsibility or the removal of the criminal character of the act. Part III- introduces the Theory of Sanction, its divisions, types, and individualization. Moreover, it indicates the reasons for mitigating and aggravating the sanction, the methods of execution, its suspension, its limitations, its alternatives, and the effects of its implementation.

prompt: Tell me about Law 263: CRIMINAL LAW II (A)
completion: LAW262 is a prerequisite course. This course aims to provide the student with the knowledge, skills and values necessary to understand the principles and detailed provisions related to the elements of each crime or a specific category of different crimes and to apply them to the various-cases related to them. Therefore, this course covers an important aspect of punitive crimes such as bribery and crimes ancillary to it, embezzlement of public funds, counterfeiting the currency circulated in the system in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, seals, stamps, signs and papers forgery crimes, drug crimes, money laundering crimes and check crimes.

prompt: Tell me about Law 369: CONFLICT OF LAWS (E)
completion: The course conflict of laws, also known as private international law, is an advanced course that follows up on the understanding gained in previous courses on private and commercial substantive law as well as procedural law. The course focuses on cross-border private and commercial legal relations. Although it introduces new theoretical concepts to the students, it is largely taught from a practical perspective of a lawyer who needs to answer the three basics questions: the courts of which state can hear the cross-border case, what will be the applicable law to the case and will such judgment be recognized and enforced in a foreign state.

prompt: Tell me about Law 380: MOOT COURT
completion: The course aims to achieve proficiency and excellence in studentss skills to apply law in practice. The final outcome of a course is a successful participation in a simulation of civil litigation, arbitration or criminal procedure in which students are prepared for their future profession of an attorney, judge or arbitrator. Vis moot on international commercial arbitration or Jessup). prompt: Tell me about Law 431: EXECUTION OF JUDGMENTS (A)
completion: This course is considered the last course in the series of Law courses. LAW 221 is a prerequisite course. This course deals with the definition of execution, the rights that may be executed, the direct authority for execution, the parties to execution, the reasons for execution, the documents necessary for execution, the expedited execution and its forms, the place of execution, and the funds that may not be executed. It also deals with procedures for seizing movable money, objecting to the seizure, seizing debtors money with others, cancellation of attachment and its effects, execution on the property and the stages of its completion, precautionary attachment and its procedures, and finally forced sale and forced eviction.

prompt: Tell me about Law 432: INSURANCE (A)
completion: This course is one of the main courses in the advanced Saudi Law course. It shows the concept of insurance, its definition, its importance, the difference between cooperative insurance and commercial insurance, its types (health insurance, vehicle insurance, life insurance), the technical bases of insurance, and insurance guarantees, the effects of insurance on the obligations of the insurance parties, the expiry of the insurance contract, and the settlement of insurance conflicts in accordance with Saudi regulations.

prompt: Tell me about Law 435: EVIDENCE LAW (A)
completion: This course covers the objective and procedural rules of proof, the different doctrines of proof, methods of proof: documentary material, testimony, circumstantial evidence, admission, oaths, expertise, court inspection, the procedures and authoritative methods of proof, the role of the judge in Islamic jurisprudence and comparative systems, the practical importance of the burden of proof, and judgments issued for proof and their characteristics.

prompt: Tell me about Law 436: CRIMINOLOGY (A)
completion: This course is taught within the course of advanced Saudi Law. It covers many important topics such as identifying the criminal phenomenon in terms of its research problems, starting with defining the concept of criminology, the content of crime and the criminal. Then, the research methods that criminology uses to investigate the facts of this phenomenon. It introduces the students to the factors that may affect a person and push him to social deviation and criminal behavior, and the punitive schools and philosophies. In addition, the forms of the criminal penalty, the methods of punitive execution, the methods of treatment within the penal institutions, and the means of aftercare for that punitive implementation.

prompt: Tell me about Law 461: INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW (E)
completion: The course aims to provide an in-depth knowledge and understanding of the laws relating to international trade. It provides a deep overview over the laws, rules and conventions on international sale of goods, trade in goods and service, carriage of goods by air, sea, and road, instruments used in various international business contract, dispute resolution etc. This course examines the distinctive issues, current relevant principles, concepts and problems involved in international trade. The course helps the student to understand the basic principles of international business and their impact on the world's economy and to learn the operational mechanism of international trade.

prompt: Tell me about Law 466: INTERNATIONAL HUMANITARIAN LAW (E)
completion: The course International Humanitarian Law is an advanced course that explores the development and application of humanitarian law also known as the law of armed conflict. The course focuses on the underlying principles governing armed conflicts and enables a careful evaluation of the various international humanitarian rules intended to protect victims during armed conflict and civil wars. The course is based on many cases from the International Criminal Court to provide a greater understanding of the application of the law of armed conflict at the practical level in the contemporary operating environment.

prompt: Tell me about Law 468: DISPUTE SETTLEMENT (E)
completion: The course covers the general meaning of international dispute settlement and methods of dispute settlement. This include the definitions of various relevant terms like dispute, settlement and international disputes, the role of international law and institutional institutions in relation to dispute settlements, causes of international disputes and participants in international disputes. It covers also the methods of dispute settlement which include direct methods, third party intervention, the regional approach and judicial settlement. The process for international dispute settlement involving the arbitral tribunal and new model for dispute settlement shall be covered too.

prompt: Tell me about Law 492: COOPERATIVE TRAINING
completion: COOP is a career related professional program available to all Law students. It is designed to help students build on skills already learned in the classroom and acquire new ones as well. COOP education is available to university students who have accumulated 90 or more credits. The COOP option counts for 10 credit hours (CRs) in practical experience over a 7 month period - usually spanning one semester and a summer.

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 104 ANALYTIC READING AND WRITING?
completion: This course aims at fulfilling the needs of reading and writing of students of the translation and linguistics major. The course integrates reading and essay writing skills at the upper-intermediate level. It equips students with vital academic vocabulary that can improve their writing skills and enable them to write at a higher thinking level. The skills gained on this course will enable students to link writing well to reading related texts and analyzing them artistically which will improve their creative and critical thinking skills in their essay writing.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 107 ENGLISH GRAMMAR I?
completion: This course aims at preparing students to apply English grammar in formal contexts at an upper-intermediate level. The course integrates different kinds of activities to bridge the gap between basic knowledge of grammatical structure and its applications. It is designed to help students enhance their understanding of English grammar, expand their already learned skills and enable them to apply it their usage of English. The course will review parts of speech and their function, different verb tenses, active and passive voice, and types of clauses.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 108 ENGLISH GRAMMAR II?
completion: This course builds on the skills learned in ELAN 107 ENG Grammar and raises the students' grammar skills to the advanced level. The course aims at building the students' grammar skills that are based on practical rather than theoretical considerations. Areas covered in the course include real and unreal conditionals, direct - indirect speech, specification of numbers in English, use of certain modals, negatives and types of questions.

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 130 INTRODUCTION TO LINGUISTICS?
completion: Students are introduced to general linguistics and its major components are studied in detail. Levels of linguistic analysis are tackled according to the following hierarchy: phonetic, phonology, morphology, syntax and semantics. Students apply what they have learned on the theoretical level to of some selected spoken and written texts.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 131 PHONETICS AND PHONOLOGY?
completion: The main objective of this course is to introduce students to the description of the English sound system (vowels and consonants). Students are given intensive practice in the production and transcription of consonants and vowels in different positions and combinations. Features of connected speech are covered as well. Suprasegmental features of English such as stress, pitch, intonation are examined and practical exercises employed throughout the course enable them to use phonetic transcription effectively.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 232 MORPHOLOGY AND SYNTAX?
completion: The course introduces the study of words, their internal structure, and how they are formed. This course is both theoretical and practical. It is theoretical in that it provides students with consider-able knowledge of morphological terms and processes. Key concepts include words vs. lexical items, inflectional and derivational morphology, compounding and morphological theories. It is practical in that it helps learners develop their skills in morphological analyses on words in English and other languages. Throughout the course, the interrelations between morphology and other sub-disciplines of Linguistics (i.e., Phonology, Semantics and Syntax) are examined.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 240 INTRODUCTION TO LITERATURE?
completion: The course explores the three major genres in English literature: Poetry, Novel, and Drama providing an overview of the development of English language/literature. The major components of literary criticism such as literary terms and critical concepts are examined with a focus on how opinion is expressed in scholarly writing.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 241 FICTION?
completion: The course is designed to acquaint students with the genre of novel as it first emerged in the 18th century in England and the reasons beyond its emergence late on the literary scene. The evolution of the novel is tracked across successive eras from 18th century through to the late 20th century with and an emphasis on the social, political, and cultural contexts prevalent in each era in the United Kingdom. The appearance and growth of the American novel in the 19th century is introduced and contrasted to its English counterpart.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 311 WESTERN THOUGHT?
completion: The course introduces the basic intellectual traditions and ideologies that define the Western World. It deals with the foundational topics leading to modernity. Students are presented a broad chronological framework that tracks and identifies the eras and their governing ideas that evolved over the past ages.

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 334 SEMANTICS AND PRAGMATICS?
completion: The first part of this course is an introduction to the study of semantics on both the word and sentence level. The second part gives insights into theories of language use, particularly the part on pragmatics dealing with how people communicate more than they literally say or write.

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 233 TEXT LINGUISTICS?
completion: The course introduces students to the notion of text as a communicative occurrence which meets certain standards of textuality. It also familiarizes students with the linguistic and pragmatic conventions of text types and genres and the differences which may exist between languages and cultures in this respect.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 250 INTRODUCTION TO TRANSLATION?
completion: This course introduces the basic concepts and elements of translation theory and practice. Items covered include approaches, methods and techniques, steps of the translation process,review, reformulation and revision. Students are familiarized with the role and functions of translator/interpreter in the process of inter-lingual communication.

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 351 SIGHT TRANSLATION?
completion: Considered as the meeting ground between translation and interpreting, sight translation joins the starting point of the written mode and the end-product of the oral one. Students are given a written text in one language and are tasked to immediately render its meaning orally into the other language. To do this proficiently, two major skills are required: 1) fast reading and comprehension of texts, 2) quick oral response into the other language. Acquisition of these skills is the focus of the course.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 352 CONSECUTIVE INTERPRETING?
completion: This course trains students in the art and skill of consecutive interpretation in both public and inter-personal situations. Techniques and strategies used by expert interpreters (such as making short hand notes and memory taking) are taught and used by the trainees in a variety of exercises.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 353 COMPUTER APPLICATIONS IN TRANSLATION?
completion: This course is an introduction to the topics and methods in the field of applied linguistics. The course emphasizes the application of applied linguistics theories to problems of second language teaching and learning and to language in social context. Topics discussed and developed include grammar and vocabulary, discourse analysis, psycholinguistics, sociolinguistics, pragmatics, corpus linguistics, functional linguistics, non-native reading research, writing, listening and speaking as well as assessment.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 354: LEXICOGRAPHY AND TERMINOLOGY?

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 355 BUSINESS AND MEDIA TRANSLATION?
completion: This course familiarizes students with the register and discourse characteristics of the language varieties of business and media in both English and Arabic. Its aims is to develop and reinforce the skills and techniques required for translating texts bearing such features into the two languages. In the fields of business, the focus is on text types such as bank statements, financial reports and business correspondence. In the field of media, text types such as news items, press reports, newsletters, and promotional texts are examined.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 356 SCIENTIFIC AND MEDICAL TRANSLATION?
completion: This course targets translation of scientific and medical texts. In the scientific field, students are trained on analyzing texts to understand the context, terms and concepts in the original text before looking for equivalencies in the other language. To best deal with medical texts, the medical terminology most commonly used by doctors and other health practitioners in text types such as medical reports, diagnosis, and medical procedures are examined with special attention given to word formation (e.g. Latin roots, suffixes and pre-fixes).
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

completion: This course targets translation of scientific and medical texts. In the scientific field, students are trained on analyzing texts to understand the context, terms and concepts in the original text before looking for equivalencies in the other language. To best deal with medical texts, the medical terminology most commonly used by doctors and other health practitioners in text types such as medical reports, diagnosis, and medical procedures are examined with special attention given to word formation (e.g. Latin roots, suffixes and pre-fixes).
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 453 SIMULTANEOUS INTERPRETING?
completion: This course offers students the opportunity to learn and apply simultaneous interpretation techniques to a variety of topics and settings. It aims to develop students' practical skills in simultaneous interpreting English to Arabic and vice versa. The focus is on strategies and techniques in dealing with simultaneous interpreting. The course surveys the different scenarios in which simultaneous interpreting is used and covers the following subject areas: motivational topics, society and social media, health, politics, and international relations.

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 455 LEGAL AND POLITICAL TRANSLATION?
completion: This course grooms skill in translating legal and political texts burdened with the complexity of structure and terminology. The essential elements of legal and political writing styles are introduced for this type of formal translation work. Text types such as court decisions, contracts, and notary deeds are dealt with. On the political side, students translate texts types such as editorial articles, speeches, diplomatic and international organizations' documents.

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 242 DRAMA?

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 243 POETRY?
completion: The course introduces students to English poetry through an in-depth practice readings and analysis of selected works of major British and American poets. The aim is to understand, analyze and appreciate poetry by determining and evaluating its aesthetic and human values. Students study a variety of major poetic types and forms. Poetic techniques such as figurative language, rhythm and meter are covered and discussed.

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 335 DISCOURSE ANALYSIS?
completion: This course explores the ways in which language varies according to subject area, social setting, communicative purpose and the social roles and identities of those involved. It examines the workings of various forms of speaking and writing - casual conversation, interviews and interrogations, public speaking, emailing and mobile phone texting and mass media articles, to cite just some examples. Students develop skills in analyzing the properties of different texts, in characterizing the interpersonal stances adopted by speakers and writers, and in identifying and classifying the various genres or texts types which operate in particular social settings.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 336 SOCIOLINGUISTICS?
completion: This course canvasses the various areas of research in sociolinguistics: the study of the relationship between language and society. The following topics are discussed: multilingualism (e.g. language choice, diglossia, and code switching), language planning, language maintenance and shift, geographical and social language variation, language change, politeness, language and gender, pidgins and creoles, language and culture, and ethnography.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELAN 460 PROFESSIONAL AND ETHICAL ISSUES?
completion: This course will provide a values-based approach to ethical professionalism and provide a method of thinking about and dealing with ethical issues in the work place. The course will provide a discussion of what a profession is and what it means to act professionally. It will include a discussion of the features of moral reasoning and provide a case resolution method for dealing with ethical issues of the work place. The course will cover in-depth those values central to moral life of any professional: integrity, respect for others, justice, compassion, and responsibility.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELP 201 WRITING FOR PROFESSIONAL COMMUNICATION?
completion: This course is designed to enhance students' writing communication skills in the context of workplace situations. The primary focus of the course is on wide array of office writing genres: text messages, emails, memos, brief business correspondences, reports, and formal business letters. Writing resumes, employment applications and follow-up letters are covered as well.

prompt: Tell me about ELP 202 ORAL COMMUNICATION FOR SOCIAL AND OCCUPATIONAL PURPOSES?
completion: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to oral communication skills in social and professional contexts. The emphasis is on learning strategies and techniques of oral communication skills in the following categories: workplace communication, office relations and career development. Students practice workplace communication exercises such as presentations and public speaking. Workplace relationship activities focused on building effective relationship, resolving conflicts, and dealing with customer services are covered as are career development skills.

prompt: Tell me about ELP 303 ENGLISH FOR ADMINISTRATION?
completion: The course offers an integrated program that allows students to gain knowledge and practice of business and administrative communication. The program includes the study of organizational structures, types of organizations, management, internal and external organizational communication and business communication environment. The nature and scope of private and public administration are surveyed. The selected topics include customer service, human resources management and negotiation theory. Planning, composing and revising administrative documents are discussed as are designing and delivering informative, positive and persuasive messages.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELP 304 ENGLISH FOR PUBLIC RELATIONS AND MARKETING?
completion: The course focuses on selected topics on public relations: roles, processes, applications, strategies and tactics. Students gain insight on the nature of public relations, its evolution, psychology, ethics, and professionalism. The course also goes over research, program planning, public opinion theory and the connection of PR to marketing, fund-raising, advertising, journalism and law.

prompt: Tell me about ELP 405 ENGLISH FOR GLOBAL MEDIA AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES?
completion: This course introduces students to the typical linguistic and extra-linguistic features of English media texts. Its aims is to promote a greater awareness of the central concerns in writing and editing English texts for the media and explores intertextual and multimedia communication in everyday life.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELP 407 ENGLISH SCIENTIFIC, TECHNICAL AND WEB-BASED WRITING?
completion: This course helps students understand different types of technical writing, desktop publishing web page design conventions. The emphasis is on style and format to achieve clarity, correctness, conciseness, and online presence in technical writing. Students enjoy liberty to choose their own topics to develop their linguistic and graphical skills and other transferable skills.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELP 408 ENGLISH FOR POLITICAL COMMUNICATION?
completion: This course looks at political communication close up. Following a brief sketch of the historical aspects of communication and public relations in politics, the course looks at fundamental themes and types of political communication, such as agenda setting, negotiation, bargaining, campaigning and branding.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ELP 492 COOPERATIVE LEARNING?
completion: The aim of the course is to provide students with an opportunity to spend a specified period of time in several local and possibly international institutions and companies, and according to a suggested work plan of training. The duration of the program is 7 months and carries a 10 credit hours weight. The evaluation and supervision of the student's performance are provided by both the hosting workplace and the relevant CH department.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 251 GENERAL TRANSLATION?
completion: This course is designed to introduce students to the basics of translation work. Through the practice of translating a variety of English and Arabic texts, students will learn to carry out the two main processes involved: analysis of source texts and reformulation into the target language. Emphasis will be on the techniques used by translators to resolve problems of subject knowledge, language and terminology. The course will also focus on the use of translation tools and resources, and on the different methods and strategies for rendering the content of texts into the other language.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description

prompt: Tell me about ETRA 358 ISSUES IN TRANSLATION?
completion: The course's aim is to sensitize students to major issues in translation studies and how to address the likely problems translators encounter in their work. Problems such as equivalence, quality assessment, gaps of terms, words and culture, requirements of knowledge, etc. are dealt with in the course.
pageType: Academics/College of Humanities and Sciences/Courses Description
